title: When will SpaceX's satellite internet service, Starlink, begin offering commercial service in North America?
preds: It's already 25 June and no news about beta testing being finished. Only that it's looking into offering wifi on commercial flights (June 2021 news).
I think it is about time to zero the gauge
need to change my forecast. Too optimistic for the past 3 months, too many forecasts.
They haven't announced a date yet.
So far they've launched about 1.5K; with plan to launch another 1.5K by the end of the year. So, not gonna happen this year.
No launch date announced. SpaceX is notorious for being too optimistic on their launch dates.
adjusting for time passed with no significant progress. They did launch more satellites recently but not enough to make this happen before June I don't think.
running out of time, no recent news I can find - their site says they need 42K sats up and they are reporting 12K

Looks like there will be plenty of customers, but still no news on when formal service to begin.  I imagine they will need at least a couple of weeks to announce.  How likely are they to say, full service from tomorrow?  So if we assume a 2 week notice period, then we have 4 weeks left until that announcement period is passed for the July 1 deadline.  Could happen, but very small. https://www.reuters.com/technology/starlink-satellite-internet-service-gets-500000-preorders-musk-says-2021-05-05/

https://www.cnbc.com/2021/04/15/spacexs-starlink-early-users-review-service-internet-speed-price.html Also found a tweet in April from Musk saying may be out of beta this summer.  That would still not hit our 1 July deadline
See many recent comments with links indicating almost zero probability. Thank you, all.

"SpaceX has not set a date for Starlink's service launch, but commercial service would not likely be offered in 2020 as it had previously planned." https://www.reuters.com/technology/starlink-satellite-internet-service-gets-500000-preorders-musk-says-2021-05-05/

Considering all of the logistics involved before it would be able to offer commercial services beyond beta testing, it remains almost certain that it will not happen before July 1st.  I am maintaining my rare 100% forecast at "Not before 1 July 2021."

When the crowd is in the same direction but more confident than I am :
(my prediction + crowd prediction) / 2
"Before the end of 2021" language seems to be recurring, makes a summer launch seem even less likely. Notching down 1%

“We do have global reach but we don’t have full connectivity globally,” Shotwell said. “We hope after about 28 launches [they've launched 24 so far], we’ll have continuous coverage throughout the globe. And then the plan after that is to continue to add satellites to provide additional capacity.”
“We still have a lot of work to do to make the network reliable,” Shotwell said. “We still have drops, not necessarily just because of where the satellites are in the sky. So we’ll move off of beta when we have a really great product that we are very proud of." This is the first comment I've seen on when they would end beta service: "when we have a really great product that we are very proud of." I think that with such a high bar, full connectivity globally would be necessary, so raising the after July bucket. The only reason there was doubt before was because we didn't know when they were going to come out of beta. They theoretically could come out of beta with just US service, but given this quote, I think they'll wait for better quality.  https://spaceflightnow.com/2021/04/06/spacex-to-ramp-up-vandenberg-launch-cadence-with-starlink-missions/

Tesla's FSD Beta began the same month as Starlink's Beta. Tesla's Beta is still... Beta mode - and Musk said a new one is to be released for continuned beta testing this month, April. Almost midway through April and still no release. I can expect Starlink Beta to last longer than FSD Beta and I am virtually certain neither Starlink nor Tesla/FSD will/can advance to commercial service without completion of beta testing. The launches are still going on as well, which signals they are still working on getting the first steps of this mission up and running. Although not completely certain, to me it does not feel like a 1/100 probability that it would be done prior to July or even June.
adjusting for time elapsed without encouraging news

Recent news kinda undermines most of the arguments I'd made for the possibility of a 2021Q2 start, they made a filing with the SEC expecting commercial service to start "before the end of 2021" (https://ecfsapi.fcc.gov/file/1042776072810/SpaceX%20Comments%20on%20Communications%20Marketplace%204.27.20.pdf). It seems that this is largely a technical limitation. They don't want to do commercial service until the service is reliable (https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2021/04/spacex-to-keep-starlink-pricing-simple-exit-beta-when-network-is-reliable/), they say they "still have a lot of work to do" on reliability, and the SEC filing bases their prediction on their "current launch cadence" for putting satellites in orbit. The "end of 2020" service is for the northern US/southern Canada, the area that they're testing the beta in most heavily and for the longest time, so it's unlikely they'd start somewhere else. "Before the end of 2020" for a Musk project facing what they describe as technical limitations is rough, it's hard to get less optimistic than that. If the commercial service start date is gated by their schedule of rocket launches, then there's no chance that that would accelerate to before June from "end of 2020" with Musk's signature delays.  I reserve some probability for it though. It's possible they'll do commercial service in a really small area by late June to see how it looks, even though that sounds like exactly what a beta is. It's also possible they'll set up some special commercial contract with a specific group. They've done pilots with the Air Force and with rural school districts to provide them service, but thus far they've lumped them under the beta umbrella. There's a chance they stop doing that and classify some specific project as commercial service, but that's not really something I'd bank too much on.

Quote from SpaceX President Gwynne Shotwell saying the firm "does not have a timeframe for getting out of the beta phase" and they have "a lot of work to do to make the network reliable." CNBC article, citing her comments at the Satellite 2021 LEO Digital Forum: https://www.cnbc.com/2021/04/06/spacexs-shotwell-no-plan-for-tiered-starlink-internet-pricing.html

According to their website: "Starlink is now delivering initial beta service both domestically and internationally, and will continue expansion to near global coverage of the populated world in 2021." Additionally, they say: "Starlink is targeting coverage in your area in mid to late 2021. You will receive a notification once your Starlink is ready to ship." https://www.starlink.com/  Before, they stated that "before the end of 2020 it will begin offering commercial service in the northern United States and southern Canada, and then will rapidly expand to near global coverage of the populated world in 2021." Because there are currently not commercial services available, it appears they are running behind schedule or waiting for a wider and more universal launch date. This makes it seem likely to me that there will be services offered in 2021 that are not in beta phase, but probably towards the end of the year.

I think we are past the moment when Starlink was scaling their satellites production. Launches look like are not a problem (never had). They will send 60 satellites every week or so. 1. In the past 3 months, Starlink has launched 570 satellites:
Jan - 70
Feb - 120
March - 180
https://www.n2yo.com/browse/?y=2021&m=03 2. Starlink also has 1318 as of the end of March. With 3 already planned launches for April, they will reach around 1500 active ones.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starlink 3. So May and June are left to prepare another step. As Elon Musk stated many times, Starlink biggest threat is negative cash flow.
“SpaceX needs to pass through a deep chasm of negative cash flow over the next year or so to make Starlink financially viable,”
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-02-09/musk-says-starlink-to-ipo-once-cash-flow-more-predictable
Starlink is making steady progress, and the official go ahead should occur in June.

Still in initial beta, and based on the wording here I expect that to continue for awhile:  "Starlink is now delivering initial beta service both domestically and internationally, and will continue expansion to near global coverage of the populated world in 2021. During beta, users can expect to see data speeds vary from 50Mb/s to 150Mb/s and latency from 20ms to 40ms in most locations over the next several months as we enhance the Starlink system. "
i hate pushing off the date on a guy who said after yesterdays Space X pad explosion - well, the craters in the right place...
It has already started in Canada.

It seems Starlink would have a lot to lose if they launch without the bandwidth and coverage to hook their clients, the earliest estimates say 'later this year' and there doesn't seem to be any firm timeline available to it seems unlikely to be available before July 1. That said, Musk isn't without his surprises so it can't be ruled out entirely...
"commercial" and "non-beta" are the limiting factors here.  I also think that they'll keep things in "beta" far longer than needed just to ensure they don't have a massive and public flop.
Following @MmeLyons777 https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1249517 Thank you for your analysis.
No news in last month (combined with change in crowd forecast) is suggesting that I should radically change my forecast

This is very difficult to accurately base rate, like I wouldn't consider most hardware or software betas as comparable, which usually take a couple months or so, to be at all comparable here. Google Fiber's trusted tester program may be closer, where programs range from 1-4 months. 2 gig Google Fiber was announced for testing in mid-September last year and made available early February this year, so 4.5 months there. The Starlink beta has been running in beta since early August 2020 (7.5 months running) and in public beta since late October/early November 2020 (4.5 months running), with a larger open beta starting late January (2 months running). I’ll need to reevaluate at the end of April, since that seems like the most likely timing for an announcement given past updates.  Pro case: Preorders for the non-beta product list a low-end ETA of mid-late 2021 for some areas of the US for the delivery. The service was originally intended to be commercially available at the beginning of this year but instead they expanded the beta, so Q2 would already include a delay as we should expect. For areas with mid-late 2021 ETA they may be deciding which areas to start offering commercial service in first, meaning some will get mid-2021 and others late-2021, but any commercial service means the question is a yes regardless of where they choose. The beta results have been very promising with very impressive speeds being delivered, meaning they likely have capacity to add a good volume of new customers, and the rollout timing should be on the lower (more optimistic) end of the spectrum since there haven’t been obvious hiccups. The price point may have delayed the rollout, but it may be worth opening up a commercial service, even if on a small scale, at the current price given the huge volume of preorders. Musk said they’d need about 800 satellites for moderate coverage of the US and they’re at over 1,000, so given that and the download speeds people are seeing in beta, commercial service is probably viable from a bandwidth perspective. They also mentioned wanting the ETC designation by the FCC by June 7 2021 to get their RDOF funding, and there’s a chance that that’ll push them to have a commercial product in the near future.  Con case: The constellation is <10% completed for the initial 12,000 satellites. The goal per Musk is global coverage by the end of the year, and after that about densifying coverage, which sounds like expanding the beta worldwide with limited capacity, and then densifying coverage to make a commercial product realistic. Their latest move was to expand the beta to more latitudes as more satellites were added in those ranges, so keeping capacity limited while the constellation is small and expanding the beta across more land areas as satellites are added at different locations would make sense and follow a past pattern. Musk also sucks with deadlines so betting on a delay is never unreasonable. They may also be waiting to release a commercial product until they can get the at-home kit to a more reasonable price point, which per their Reddit posts has been their single hardest challenge. There’s no realistic competition in this space (heh) so there may be less of a rush than other product betas like Google Fiber.

Again pushing April-June scenario. We need to take into consideration that the whole project pace will accelerate over time. I assume that minimum 250-300 new satellites (3k per year) need to be delivered every month to maintain the whole system. Even more. The announced final number is 12k, but there were proposal to increase number to 48k. As of 14th March, Starlink has 1261 operational satellites, with the next ~180 planned until April (single planned start). That is a total of 1441. In March there are already 3 successful launches, 2 planned (Jan, Feb had 2, with October holding a previous record of 3). So we can see positive, upward trend. Beta programms in EU and Ocenia. Starlink wants to 'take control over negative cashflow. This is their biggest threat, which killed all previous companies. So they want to start creating a positive inflow asap. This is where they need to scale their operation in 2021.

In a tweet (May 2020), Musk claimed that Starlink "will only work for higher latitudes (Seattle) at first, then get progressively closer to the equator" (1).  I think this tweet may be outdated / incorrect as, from playing around entering different addresses into the Starlink website's pre-order form (2), the majority of areas north of Seattle appear to have an expected coverage date of 2022. Whereas when I enter an address in Florida, I get "mid 2021" and for Mexico I get "mid-to-late 2021". I still think there's a strong chance that commercial service in at least one area of N America will be offered before 30 June [reasoning in my previous forecast & comment], though I'm adjusting to give more weight to "not before 1 July". (1) https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/1258513259168010240
(2) https://www.starlink.com/

All indications are the a full commercial release of Starlink will not occur before 1 July 2021. A news report from 11 February 2021 (https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-02-12/starlink-australia-price-availability-revealed/13144262) revealed that the company does not plan to launch commercially until the 2nd half of 2021 which would be after 1 July 2021.

Beginning this forecast with a fairly conservative base case. Will update following additional research.

I read the promo stuff.....51% surveyed would want to try starlink, average internet speed is x and starlink is yx% more, etc, etc. But as a user I'll have to pay $500 for switching apparatus. Is installation extra? What companies are ready and aligned with starlink to do the installations? Why did AT&T recently decide to spin-off Direct TV into a a separate company with a private equity JV arrangement? Is Starlink going to run the first commercial release nationwide/worldwide? Or, somehow limit it to a region? Confusing to me. It would seem with so much invested to launch and position the satellites that Starlink wouldn't want a failure (bad press) on their first  non-beta release.

Need more launches for it to work properly. With summer coming up, it is reasonable that some of the launches out of Florida may be delayed because of thunderstorms that occur during that time of year. As a proxy, Tesla's auto-pilot system is still in beta mode after 4 months to date, so we can expect longer for space services. Reason to believe they can get it done because 1) they have a plan and 2) they have FCC approval. A reason to doubt is that Elon Musk himself said Starlink is not really purposed for areas like San Francisco or New York, where there is ample connection. Nonetheless, there are pre-orders already in place in USA. Beta has been going on since late October 2020, it seems. PS: Not before 1 July 2021 contains more days of the year (infinitely greater than the other choices combined), so our best bet without any knowledge would be to choose the last one. It is also consistent with the planning fallacy and Musk's tendency to underestimate the time it takes to complete his own projects. I cannot reject the other bins because it is reasonably close to the "mid 2020" forecast from Musk and is consistent with a time that is longer than 4 months for Tesla's FSD beta which is ongoing. Feb. 28 UPDATE : I am unsure if there will be summer launches. I am aware of those planned for March. I challenge someone to challenge my forecast probabilities. Am I too pessimistic? Hit me with challenging evidence, fellow nerds.

A handful of data points that I think are relevant here: 1) "Better Than Nothing Beta" has been running since Oct 2020 with service priced at $99 a month, in addition to a $499 upfront cost.
This suggests that Starlink is at least already functional in many parts of N. America.
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/01/20/spacex-expands-starlink-public-beta-test-to-canada-united-kingdom.html 2) They recently opened pre-orders in areas of US, claiming a "mid to late 2021" timeframe for some states and a 2022 timeframe for others. The fact that some areas are listed as 2022 suggests that the "mid to late 2021" will actually skew late 2021. However, it only needs to be commercially available in ONE area before then for the outcome to be satisfied.
https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2021/02/spacex-starlink-now-taking-pre-orders-for-service-in-mid-to-late-2021/ 3) On Feb 9th, Musk posted two tweets: 
"SpaceX needs to pass through a deep chasm of negative cash flow over the next year or so to make Starlink financially viable. Every new satellite constellation in history has gone bankrupt. We hope to be the first that does not."
...
"Once we can predict cash flow reasonably well, Starlink will IPO"
This suggests that cash flow is a relatively big concern for Starlink - hence why they've opened up pre-orders. This suggests to me that Starlink will be incentivised to begin commercial services ASAP. However, they'll also want to balance this with long-term success 
https://www.engadget.com/spacex-starlink-internet-preorders-121427490.html?guccounter=1&guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly9lbi53aWtpcGVkaWEub3JnLw&guce_referrer_sig=AQAAAGz2ggUjyPug1o1Op-32ZrV5Bgc3tCeF8Yej2EMmHKvRzbBTfnXdRf50QC7Mf79db5B28gfDnIm5mBCRVagsRO1atwUSaxlc6RG425hkmgOUiOyIG1Pg9715W7SO6mWXjyFPycxxEXuFehzaGh5aorTUmrW3I0mUubNtHwPvlx5e 4) There are approx 1,000 satellites in orbit right now (1145 according to Wikipedia). Each upcoming launch will deploy ~60 additional satellites. There have been 4 launches since beginning of year & looking at upcoming schedule, it appears to remain at about 1 launch every 2 weeks for foreseeable future (+120 satellites / month).
By 31st March: ~1265
By 30th April: ~1385
By 31st May: ~1505
By 30th June: ~1725
Unsure number of satellites that would be needed for launch of commercial services but the relative increase in the number of satellites that will be in orbit between 1 April 2021 and 30 June 2021 versus number that are in orbit now is substantial. Given that beta testing was possible with <1000, these numbers suggest that commercial services will be possible (?)

Paradigm shift
"Speaking on a November 21st Reddit Ask Me Anything (AMA) thread, one of the SpaceX Starlink engineers participating revealed that the company is targeting a “wider beta” rollout as early as late-January 2021. Despite having some 820 functioning Starlink satellites in orbit, approximately a third were recently launched and are still raising their orbits or waiting in phasing orbits to properly orient themselves and maximize Starlink internet coverage."
"While it’s effectively impossible to predict which orbital ‘plane’ a given batch of Starlink satellites is targeting, it’s likely that the ~300 spacecraft still making their way to operational orbits will complete their journeys within the next 60 days. In general, it takes roughly 2-3 months from any given Starlink launch for all ~60 satellites to reach their operational 550 km (~340 mi) orbits, a process usually performed in batches of 22 – each essentially representing one evenly-space ring of internet coverage a few hundred miles wide."

SpaceX, the private spaceflight company known for reusable rockets and a giant, shiny Starship, will begin offering its own satellite internet service in 2020, according to SpaceNews. In fact, the U.S. Air Force is already testing it in planes. To build the service, SpaceX will have to launch up to eight Falcon 9 rockets filled with the company's Starlink satellites, SpaceX President and Chief Operating Officer Gwynne Shotwell told SpaceNews and other reporters this week at the 70th International Astronautical Congress in Washington. "We'll continue to upgrade the network until mid to late next year," SpaceNews' Jeff Foust quoted Shotwell as saying during a media roundtable on Tuesday (Oct. 22). "We're hoping for 24 launches by the end of the year." https://www.starlink.com/

Wikipedia: As of September 2020, SpaceX is launching up to 60 satellites at a time, aiming to deploy 1,440[10] of the 260 kilograms (570 lb) spacecraft to provide near-global service by late 2021 or 2022.[11] SpaceX was initially targeting a private beta service in the Northern United States and Canada by August 2020 with a public beta following in November 2020, service beginning at high latitudes between 44°-52° North.[12][13] Concerns have been raised about the long-term danger of space debris resulting from placing thousands of satellites in orbits above 600 kilometres (370 mi),[14][15] as well as the negative impact to observational and radio astronomy on Earth.[16] In response, SpaceX has lowered the Starlink satellite orbits to 550 kilometres (340 mi) or below,[17] and launched prototype satellites with anti-reflective coating[18] and an experimental sunshade.[19]

With hardware/software products like these that is expensive, hard-to-build, and difficult to deploy, the iterations after getting feedback can be quite slow, and there are likely many bugs that will come up during the testing program.
The additional compounding factor is that it is difficult to install satellite dishes on people's roofs, and so SpaceX will have to either partner with a number of installation service providers across the US/Canada, or release a much easier way to mount the systems, which will likely be a big problem in the beta that will need to be solved before a commercial release.

Since 2010, SpaceX has averaged .75 successful launches a month - or 3 successful launches every 4 months. However, that rate has increased dramatically with 13 successful launches in 2020 as of August 18 - which is another reason averages are deceiving....  there are 5 additional Starlink launches scheduled for 2020. [1] SpaceX has conducted 11 successful Starlink launches as of August 18, placing a total of 595 satelites into LEO [2] Starlink can reach Canada and the northern United States with 12 launches, and there are 3 more Starlink launches scheduled for September, 2020. [1] Starlink can reach nearly all the populated world after 24 successful launches. [2] Beta Testing is underway, so the question in my mind is "who is the target audience for this service?" It appears that the obvious clients are people who currently do not have access to a broadband connection. Only 6% of the U.S. population lack broadband, so it seems unlikely that Starlink will open commercial service after 12 launches - although, 6% is 19 million potential customers (but not really, more on that below)...... [3] The Beta Test appears to be scheduled for 8 weeks. Having started end of July - beginning of August, that brings it to completion by the end of September or beginning of October. [4] Starlink will have conduct 14 launches by then, so theoretically they will be able to service all of North America and Canada by then. They'll likely take at least a month following the Beta Test to process the data and make tweaks. There are two Starlink launches left in 2020 at this point, one in November, and one December 1st.[1] Given Elon Musk's habit of launching his products in North America and Canada first before expanding globally, it would make sense to appeal. 6% of Canadians lack internet, which amounts to about 2.25 million potential customers. 19 million potential U.S. customers does not equal U.S. households..... according to the 2010 census [5], 76% of Americans were 18 years or older (21.25 x .76 = 16.15).  48.2% of Americans are married ((16.15 x .482)/2)+(16.15 x .518) = 12.25785 million U.S. potential households - not accounting for people who have roommates and share an internet account. Meanwhile, in Canada, there are 1.8594 million Canadians who are over 18 and lack internet. 56% are married, so ((1.8594 x .56)/2) + (1.8594 x .44) = 1.338768 million potential Canadian households. 12.25785 million + 1.338768 million = 13.596618 million potential customers. Each Falcon Heavy 9 rocket costs about $57 million to launch [6], so after the minimum 12 launches SpaceX will have spent upwards of $684 million on the hopes of servicing only 13.596618 million customers. This ignores the fact that SpaceX launches other company's satellites into orbit for a profit, so they've been making money.... Starlink will offer speeds up to 1GB, which right now costs between $80 - $100 in America. Lets say that they want to undercut the competition and offer it for $50 a month. $50 x 13.596618 = $680 million per month. This assumes a lot, including that all who lack internet will sign up for Starlink. About 10% of Americans don't use internet [7], so $50 x (13.596618 x .9) = $611.8 million per month. For those that don't have internet currently, how likely are they to hear about Starlink so that they sign up? Will Elon have to advertise on radio, TV, or in the paper? Tesla famously relies on earned media, social media, and word of mouth. I'm not sure if that's sufficient for this product. The point is, while I think that its financially viable - desirable, in fact - to launch this service in North America as soon as possible after the Beta Test, I think it will take some time to create awareness. So, I'm leaning away from a 2020 commercial launch. [1] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Falcon_9_and_Falcon_Heavy_launches
[2] https://spaceflightnow.com/2020/08/07/spacex-closes-out-busy-week-with-launch-of-more-starlink-satellites/
[3] https://www.fcc.gov/reports-research/reports/broadband-progress-reports/eighth-broadband-progress-report
[4] https://www.inverse.com/innovation/spacex-starlink-beta-test-how-to-sign-up#:~:text=The%20beta%20test%20is%20aimed,eight%2Dweek%20period%20of%20testing.
[5] https://www.census.gov/prod/cen2010/briefs/c2010br-03.pdf
[6] https://www.airspacemag.com/space/is-spacex-changing-the-rocket-equation-132285884/#:~:text=But%20what%20really%20sets%20SpaceX,%242%2C500%20per%20pound%20to%20orbit.
[7] https://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2019/04/22/some-americans-dont-use-the-internet-who-are-they/
Not until they meet the regulatory thresholds

While SpaceX is barely a tenth of the way to Starlink’s first ~4400-satellite phase, a May 2020 interview with Gwynne Shotwell revealed that the company intends to open the Starlink beta program to the public once 14 batches of satellites are safely in orbit. Based on recent FCC-SpaceX interactions, it appears that the company is excluding v0.9 satellite prototypes from the operational count, implying that said public beta can begin to roll out once the Starlink V1 L14 (Starlink-14) launch is complete and the satellite batch has boosted into its final orbit.
Lots more satellites to deploy, lots of hardware and software to debug and marketing and subscription service to define and implement before this can be offered as a commercial service.

Space X has put 478 out of 600 Starlink satellites in 2020 so far. That is an estimate of around 750 per year. Another way to look at satellites per year number are launches per month (right now once per month with 60 satellites).
SpaceX state that they need to put 1,584 satellites to start providing the service. So 1584 - 600 = 984 left. Even with two launches per month, it will take them 8-9 months (as they sell part of the space to utilizing room through rideshare brokers).
Production is at 120 per month level, so it will take also 8 months to produce such a number of satellites. So SpaceX would need to increase both production and launch frequency to start the service after April 2021. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Starlink#cite_note-10

Ended up relatively close to the crowd's predictions. I'm not extremely bullish on this taking place this year for a few reasons. 1. Elon's companies tend to declare very aggressive timelines that are extremely hard to hit in practice. This is great for goal setting, but sets me to think prediction wise that things will happen behind that aggressive schedule.
2. As many have posted, there have been some leaked testing results. You could probably go two ways on those: the results are far below what was promised meaning they'll want to hold off from a reputation standpoint, OR those results are on par or better than what people get in rural US today, meaning they might be desirable and could start generating revenue for SpaceX. With those points, I'll tend to push latter. I think they could start earlier and be aggressive, but they'll also want to make a splash once they start. And consumer industries are extremely fickle, you don't want to launch a product and create a bad brand reputation. Something they've worked very hard to avoid with Tesla. Seems to me we should expect this to take some time to become operational.

Hundreds in orbit for beta testing, thousands needed for global operation, lots of testing and bug fixing in between. The definition of "commercial service" is hard to pin down. Does that mean one contract with one user or a service offered for general sale across the North America? Beta testing could take 6 months or more as the satellites and ground stations and operational software are all in play. Just orienting the constellations is work that no one has really done before at this scale. How long will it operationally take to align constellations for commercial service?  Debugging the ground hardware and software is also a challenge, all being done simultaneously.

Speed tests reportedly ranging from 11Mbps to 60Mbps.  Testers signed non disclosure agreements so this is mostly coming from anonymous posters on the web. "While 60Mbps isn't a gigabit, it's on par with some of the lower cable speed tiers and is much higher than speeds offered by many DSL services in the rural areas where SpaceX is likely to see plenty of interest. On the Reddit thread, some Internet users said they'd love to get the speeds shown in the Starlink tests as they are currently stuck at 1Mbps or even less."  https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2020/08/spacex-starlink-beta-tests-show-speeds-up-to-60mbps-latency-as-low-as-31ms/

https://spaceflightnow.com/2020/08/07/spacex-closes-out-busy-week-with-launch-of-more-starlink-satellites/
It needs 24 launches to be fully operational. It is at 10 launches. Needs 12 for Canada and too part of US coverage. One launch a month is what I read somewhere that they can manage. They are already Beta testing and wanted to have this active in 2020. We are talking December at the earliest but probably not as more testing will take awhile once 12 are up there. Tech time tends to slide so more like middle of next year. Need more signals to be clearer for the forecast :-)
Watching for announcement of launch of 400th satelite at which time it powers the system up.
